titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I read before the arrival of my tea the book of the Confessions in which S. Augustine describes the spiritual crisis in which he was "converted". Nothing could have been more gradual and deliberate than his passage from Manichaeism to the Catholic Church. The last phase had been prepared for by years of thought and conflict. And no doubt it was the same with his great master S. Paul. There is really nothing sudden in religion. Always there has been a preparatis evangelica, though the man himself may hardly have been conscious of it.

Ernest and I left the Castle at 9.20 a.m., & motored to South Shields (32 miles), where I preached, & celebrated the Holy Communion. There was a fair congregation & perhaps as many as 60 communicants. The curate, Griffiths, read Mattins very well, but I fear his voice is too weak for that church. We returned to the Castle after the service.

In the afternoon I stayed in my study, & read a very interesting book by a Dutch Professor, Huizinga on "The Waning of the Middle Ages, a study of the forms of life, thought, and Art in France & the Netherlands in the XIVth and XVth centuries". Also I wrote to George Nimmins.
After dinner I read aloud Froude's account of the Oxford Movement.
The weather was dull, misty, and wet all day long.
